title: Misrepresentation
text:
Misrepresenting data science results
Some common ways people do this, either intentionally or unintentionally, include:


Claiming causality where it’s not in the scope of inference of the underlying study
Distorting axes and scales to make the data tell a different story
Visualizing spatial areas instead of human density for issues that depend on and affect humans
Omitting uncertainty in reporting

title: Misrepresentation
text:
TIME coverage

How plausible is the statement in the title of this article?




Alice Park. Exercise Can Lower Risk of Some Cancers By 20%. Time Magazine. 16 May 2016.

title: Misrepresentation
text:
LA Times coverage

What does “research shows” mean?




Melissa Healy. Exercising drives down risk for 13 cancers, research shows.
Los Angeles Times. 16 May 2016.

title: Misrepresentation
text:
Original study
Moore, Steven C., et al. “Association of leisure-time physical activity with risk of 26 types of cancer in 1.44 million adults.” JAMA internal medicine 176.6 (2016): 816-825.


Volunteers were asked about their physical activity level over the preceding year.
Half exercised less than about 150 minutes per week, half exercised more.
Compared to the bottom 10% of exercisers, the top 10% had lower rates of esophageal, liver, lung, endometrial, colon, and breast cancer.
Researchers found no association between exercising and 13 other cancers (e.g. pancreatic, ovarian, and brain).



Carl Bergstrom and Jevin West. Calling Bullshit: The art of skepticism in a data-driven world.
Random House, 2020.
Sharon Begley. “Does exercise prevent cancer?”. StatNews. 16 May 2016.

title: Misrepresentation
text:
Tax cuts

What is the difference between these two pictures? Which presents a better way to represent these data?




Christopher Ingraham. “You’ve been reading charts wrong. Here’s how a pro does it.”. The Washington Post. 14 October 2019.

title: Algorithmic bias
text:
Garbage in, garbage out

In statistical modeling and inference we talk about “garbage in, garbage out” – if you don’t have good (random, representative) data, results of your analysis will not be reliable or generalizable.
Corollary: Bias in, bias out.

title: Algorithmic bias
text:
Google Translate

What might be the reason for Google’s gendered translation? How do ethics play into this situation?




Source: Engadget - Google is working to remove gender bias in its translations

title: Algorithmic bias
text:
Google Translate



Source: Reducing gender bias in Google Translate

title: Algorithmic bias
text:
Amazon’s experimental hiring algorithm


Used AI to give job candidates scores ranging from one to five stars – much like shoppers rate products on Amazon
Amazon’s system was not rating candidates for software developer jobs and other technical posts in a gender-neutral way; it taught itself that male candidates were preferable




Gender bias was not the only issue. Problems with the data that underpinned the models’ judgments meant that unqualified candidates were often recommended for all manner of jobs, the people said.




Jeffrey Dastin. Amazon scraps secret AI recruiting tool that showed bias against women. Reuters. 10 Oct 2018.

title: Algorithmic bias
text:
Facial recognition



Joy Buolamwini and Timnit Gebru’s research identified that gender and skin-type bias in commercial artificial-intelligence systems used in facial recognition software.
Examination of facial-analysis software showed an error rate of 0.8% for light-skinned men vs. 34.7% for dark-skinned women.
A major U.S. technology company that designs facial recognition software claimed an accuracy rate of more than 97%, but the data set used to assess its performance was more than 77% male and more than 83% white.






Study finds gender and skin-type bias in commercial artificial-intelligence systems

title: Algorithmic bias
text:
Criminal sentencing
2016 ProPublica article on algorithm used for rating a defendant’s risk of future crime:



Source: Julia Angwin, Jeff Larson, Surya Mattu, and Lauren Kirchner. Machine Bias. 23 May 2016. ProPublica.

title: Algorithmic bias
text:
Risk score errors

What is common among the defendants who were assigned a high/low risk score for reoffending?

title: Algorithmic bias
text:
ProPublica analysis
Data: Risk scores assigned to >7,000 people arrested in Broward County, FL + whether they were charged with new crimes over the following 2 years.

Results:


20% of those predicted to commit violent crimes actually did.
Algorithm had higher accuracy (61%) when full range of crimes taken into account (e.g. misdemeanors). 
Algorithm was more likely to falsely flag black defendants as future criminals, at almost twice the rate as white defendants.
White defendants were mislabeled as low risk more often than black defendants.

title: Algorithmic bias
text:
Risk scores

How can an algorithm that doesn’t use race as input data be racist?

title: Algorithmic bias
text:
Predicting ethnicity
Improving Ecological Inference by Predicting Individual Ethnicity from Voter Registration Record (Imran and Khan, 2016)

In both political behavior research and voting rights litigation, turnout and vote choice for different racial groups are often inferred using aggregate election results and racial composition. Over the past several decades, many statistical methods have been proposed to address this ecological inference problem. We propose an alternative method to reduce aggregation bias by predicting individual-level ethnicity from voter registration records. Building on the existing methodological literature, we use Bayes’s rule to combine the Census Bureau’s Surname List with various information from geocoded voter registration records. […] We provide open-source software to implement the proposed methodology. The open-source software is available for implementing the proposed methodology.

title: Algorithmic bias
text:
wru package
The said “source software” is the wru package: https://github.com/kosukeimai/wru.

Do you have any ethical concerns about installing this package?

title: Algorithmic bias
text:
Parting thoughts

At some point during your data science learning journey you will learn tools that can be used unethically



You might also be tempted to use your knowledge in a way that is ethically questionable either because of business goals or for the pursuit of further knowledge (or because your boss told you to do so)




How do you train yourself to make the right decisions (or reduce the likelihood of accidentally making the wrong decisions) at those points?

title: Misleading Data Visualizations
text:
Programming exercises are designed to provide an opportunity for you to put what you learn in the videos and readings. These exercises feature interactive code chunks using a tool called WebR, which allow you to write, edit, and run R code without leaving your browser.
When the ▶️ Run Code button turns to a solid color (with no flashing loading bubble), you can interact with the code chunks!
We invite you to think critically about the ethics questions associated with each graph before opening the solution box so you get the most out of this exercise.

title: Misleading Data Visualizations
text:
Programming exercises are designed to provide an opportunity for you to put what you learn in the videos and readings. These exercises feature interactive code chunks using a tool called WebR, which allow you to write, edit, and run R code without leaving your browser.
When the ▶️ Run Code button turns to a solid color (with no flashing loading bubble), you can interact with the code chunks!
We invite you to think critically about the ethics questions associated with each graph before opening the solution box so you get the most out of this exercise.

title: Misleading Data Visualizations
text:
Packages
We’ll use: tidyverse and scales to create plots in this exercise. These are ready for you to use in this programming exercise!

library(tidyverse)
library(scales)

title: Misleading Data Visualizations
text:
Motivation
Data visualization is a powerful tool used to help a general audience synthesize complex data into a message that is understandable. However, data visualizations that are intentionally or unintentionally misleading can lead an audience to conclusions that are nothing more than fabrications of the truth.
In this programming exercise, we are going to visit data from the Covid-19 pandemic, and work through two different data visualizations, identifying why they are misleading, and how they can be improved.

title: Misleading Data Visualizations
text:
Kansas Covid
“On August 6, 2020, Rachel Maddow of MSNBC tweeted “Chart: Kansas mask counties versus no-mask mandate counties” (Maddow 2020, August 6) along with a link to a plot (see figure below) created by the Kansas Department of Health and Environment—which was also shared live on The Rachel Maddow Show that same day. The plot compared the number of COVID-19 cases over time for counties in Kansas that had mask mandates versus those that did not” (Engledowl and Weiland 2021)
The data used to create the data visualization can be read in (to be used later), and seen below by running the following code.










What is misleading about this graph? Why might it be misleading?







Discussion





There are two different y-axes. One on the left for the counties with the mask mandate, and one on the right for the counties without a mask mandate. This may be misleading, as someone may not see the additional y-axis on the right side of the graph; line graphs typically do not have two different y-axes.






What trend in these data might someone conclude because of the misleading visualization?







Discussion





Based on the misleading visualization, one could come to the conclusion that, the Kansas Covid-19 7 day rolling averages per/100k between the dates of 7/12/2020 through 8/03/2020 decreased to a lower value for masked counties than for counties that did not have the mask mandate

title: Misleading Data Visualizations
text:
Fixing the graph
Now that we have identified how this graph is misleading, let’s create our own graph that fixes the issue! The first thing we need to do is think about the structure of our data. As seen above, our three column names are date, mask mandate, and no-mask mandate.

How do the structure of these data need to change in order for us to plot these data?







Solution





The values of mask mandate and no-mask mandate need to be levels of a categorical variable that we can map to the visual element (lines) on our plot. In the following code below, we name this variable County.

kansas_covid |>
  pivot_longer(!date, names_to = "County" , values_to = "cases") 

# A tibble: 46 × 3
   date      County          cases
   <chr>     <chr>           <dbl>
 1 7/12/2020 mask mandate     25.2
 2 7/12/2020 no-mask mandate   9.8
 3 7/13/2020 mask mandate     19.7
 4 7/13/2020 no-mask mandate   9.2
 5 7/14/2020 mask mandate     19.7
 6 7/14/2020 no-mask mandate   9.4
 7 7/15/2020 mask mandate     20.4
 8 7/15/2020 no-mask mandate   9.8
 9 7/16/2020 mask mandate     19.7
10 7/16/2020 no-mask mandate   9.9
# ℹ 36 more rows







Now that our data is in the correct format (note that we also changed our date variable to be in the format of month, day, year), we are going to use ggplot(), and the appropriate geom function to make our new graph. Please see the Function Reference for the different types of geoms we can use. Add the appropriate geom to the plot below to make a line graph.
















Solution





We can use geom_line() to create a line graph!

kansas_covid |>
  pivot_longer(!date, names_to = "County" , values_to = "cases") |>
  mutate(date = as.Date(date, format = "%m/%d/%Y")) |>
  ggplot(
    aes(x = date , y = cases , color = County)
  ) +
  geom_line()














Using our new graph, what proper conclusion can we make?







Discussion





Based on our new graph, we can see the Kansas Covid-19 7 day rolling averages per/100k between the dates of 7/12/2020 through 8/03/2020 decreased for the mask mandated counties, and stayed relatively consistent for the non-masked mandated counties. We can also see that within this date range, the non-mask mandated counties had a lower rolling average per/100k than masked mandated counties.





We can add the following lines of code to make the graph even more effective. We are using scale_color_manual() to change the colors of the line associated with the County variable; scale_x_date()to add date labels to the x-axis; theme()to change the angle of the x-axis and the position of the legend; and labs() to add a title! We also have given a subset of dates, and removed having an angled x-axis to improve readability for the user.

title: Misleading Data Visualizations
text:
Georgia Covid
Georgia DPH temporarily published the following graph on the COVID-19 Daily Status Report. The data and associated plot can be found below. These data are pulled from the NY Times.













What is misleading about this graph? Why might it be misleading?







Discussion





The dates on the x-axis are not in chronological order. This is extremely misleading, and a general audience is going to assume a correct chronological order to the dates from left to right. Further, the order of the counties within date are sorted from highest to lowest, making cross date comparison more difficult for each county. One strategy we can use in R is to manually set the dates in chronological order using the levels argument in the factor() function when manipulating the date variable in our data set using mutate().

georgia_covid |>
  filter(date >= "2020-04-26", date <= "2020-05-09") |>
  mutate(
    date = format(date, "%d%b%Y"), 
    date = factor(
      date,
      levels = c("26Apr2020", "27Apr2020", "28Apr2020", 
                 "29Apr2020", "30Apr2020", "01May2020", 
                 "02May2020", "03May2020", "04May2020",
                 "05May2020", "06May2020", "07May2020", 
                 "08May2020", "09May2020")))

# A tibble: 70 × 7
   date      county   state    fips cases deaths  case
   <fct>     <chr>    <chr>   <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl>
 1 26Apr2020 Cobb     Georgia 13067  1428     75    33
 2 26Apr2020 DeKalb   Georgia 13089  1800     36    12
 3 26Apr2020 Fulton   Georgia 13121  2545     94     2
 4 26Apr2020 Gwinnett Georgia 13135  1504     47    44
 5 26Apr2020 Hall     Georgia 13139  1033     11     1
 6 27Apr2020 Cobb     Georgia 13067  1483     81    55
 7 27Apr2020 DeKalb   Georgia 13089  1855     42    55
 8 27Apr2020 Fulton   Georgia 13121  2680    103   135
 9 27Apr2020 Gwinnett Georgia 13135  1545     52    41
10 27Apr2020 Hall     Georgia 13139  1098     12    65
# ℹ 60 more rows


Dates on our plot will appear in the order we set!






What trend in these data might someone conclude because of the misleading visualization?







Discussion





Based on the misleading visualization, one could come to the conclusion that the trend of Covid-19 cases across these five counties are significantly decreasing each day.

title: Misleading Data Visualizations
text:
Fixing the graph
We can use the following code to help make their plot less misleading. We will not sort the levels of county within each date to be in descending order, to make comparisons easier. The function geom_col() is used to re-create the barplot. The functions theme(), scale_x_discrete(), and scale_fill_manual() are used to help recreate some of the visual features of the plot above.

georgia_covid |>
  filter(date >= "2020-04-26", date <= "2020-05-09") |>
  mutate(
    date = format(date, "%d%b%Y"), 
    date = factor(
      date,
      levels = c("26Apr2020", "27Apr2020", "28Apr2020", 
                 "29Apr2020", "30Apr2020", "01May2020", 
                 "02May2020", "03May2020", "04May2020",
                 "05May2020", "06May2020", "07May2020", 
                 "08May2020", "09May2020"))) |>
  ggplot(aes(x = date, y = case, group = county, fill = county)) +
  geom_col(position = position_dodge(), width=.8) + 
  scale_x_discrete(guide = guide_axis(n.dodge = 2)) +
  scale_fill_manual(
    "County",
     values = c("#5854A8", "#46868E", "#958648", "#8F5D37", "#5D98DB"),
     guide = guide_legend(title.position = "top", title.hjust = 0.5)) + 
  labs(
    title = "Top 5 Counties with the Greatest Number of Confirmed COVID-19 Cases",
    subtitle = "The chart below represents the most impacted counties over the 
    past 15 days and the number of cases over time." ) +
  theme_classic() +
  theme(
    legend.position = "top", 
    panel.background = element_rect(fill = "#182F4E"),
    plot.background = element_rect(fill = "#182F4E"),
    axis.line = element_line(color = "white"),
    axis.text = element_text(color = "white"),
    axis.title = element_text(color = "white"),
    legend.background = element_rect(fill = "#182F4E"),
    legend.text = element_text(color = "white"),
    legend.title = element_text(color = "white"),
    title = element_text(color = "white"))









Using our new graph, what proper conclusion can we make about the trend of casses across the five counties?







Discussion





Based on the less misleading graph, we can see that the overall trend of cases across the five counties may have gone down, but the rate in which they went down depends on the county. Further, some counties (ex. Hall) show a more cyclic pattern than an overall downward trend.






What are some of your overall takeaways after working with these two misleading graphs?







Takeaways





– We digest information from graphs very quickly. If data are misrepresented, it may not be initially obvious, leading to some making incorrect conclusions.
– Data cane be manipulated based on their axes. If you are creating / consuming graphed information, it’s important to be cognizant of the scale and order in which information on the axes are in.
– Plotting data in a unfamiliar way (ex. having two y-axes) can be misleading, instead of a helpful comparison tool. As a researcher, think critically about how your audience is going scan your visualization.

title: Sector and services (Complete)
text:
The following chart was shared by @GraphCrimes on X/Twitter on September 3, 2022.
Our ultimate goal in this code along is to identify aspects of misrepresentation in this plot and then to correct them.








We will use the tidyverse package for data wrangling and visualization.

library(tidyverse)




These data come from Survation and were recreated from the percentages noted on the segmented bar chart above.

survation <- read_csv("https://data-science-with-r.github.io/data/survation.csv")

Let’s take a look at the data.

survation

# A tibble: 1,858 × 5
      ID `Royal Mail`  Energy        Water         Rail         
   <dbl> <chr>         <chr>         <chr>         <chr>        
 1  1308 Public sector Public sector Public sector Public sector
 2  1018 Public sector Public sector Public sector Public sector
 3  1125 Public sector Public sector Public sector Public sector
 4  1004 Public sector Public sector Public sector Public sector
 5   623 Public sector Public sector Public sector Public sector
 6   905 Public sector Public sector Public sector Public sector
 7   645 Public sector Public sector Public sector Public sector
 8   934 Public sector Public sector Public sector Public sector
 9   400 Public sector Public sector Public sector Public sector
10   900 Public sector Public sector Public sector Public sector
# ℹ 1,848 more rows

Let’s take a look at the data.

# A tibble: 1,858 × 5

   <dbl> <chr>         <chr>         <chr>         <chr>

title: Sector and services (Complete)
text:
Critique
What is misleading about this graph?
The graph is misleading because the segments are not to scale (e.g., making it seem like the difference between public, private, and don’t know are closer than the data shows).

title: Sector and services (Complete)
text:
Recreate and improve

Confirm that the data match the percentages from the visualization. That is, calculate the percentages of public sector, private sector, don’t know for each of the services and check that they match the percentages from the plot.


survation_longer <- survation |>
  pivot_longer(
    cols = -ID,
    names_to = "service",
    values_to = "sector"
  )

survation_longer |>
  count(service, sector) |>
  group_by(service) |>
  mutate(prop = round(n / sum(n), 2))

# A tibble: 12 × 4
# Groups:   service [4]
   service    sector             n  prop
   <chr>      <chr>          <int> <dbl>
 1 Energy     Don't know       130  0.07
 2 Energy     Private sector   112  0.06
 3 Energy     Public sector   1616  0.87
 4 Rail       Don't know        56  0.03
 5 Rail       Private sector    56  0.03
 6 Rail       Public sector   1746  0.94
 7 Royal Mail Don't know       149  0.08
 8 Royal Mail Private sector   130  0.07
 9 Royal Mail Public sector   1579  0.85
10 Water      Don't know        56  0.03
11 Water      Private sector    56  0.03
12 Water      Public sector   1746  0.94



Create an improved version of the visualization. Your improved visualization:
should also be a segmented bar chart with services on the y-axis and presented in the same order as the original plot; sectors should create segments of the plot using the same colors (gray, #FF3205, and #006697) and appear in the same order as the original plot
should have the same legend location
should have the same title and caption
does not need to have a bolded title or a gray background
does not need to show percentages in the segments


survation_longer |>
  mutate(
    service = fct_relevel(
      service, "Royal Mail", "Energy", "Water", "Rail"
    ),
    sector = fct_rev(
      fct_relevel(sector, "Public sector", "Private sector", "Don't know"))
    ) |>
  ggplot(aes(y = service, fill = sector)) +
  geom_bar() +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("gray", "#FF3205", "#006697")) +
  guides(fill = guide_legend(reverse = TRUE)) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(legend.position = "bottom") +
  labs(
    x = NULL,
    y = NULL,
    fill = NULL,
    title = "Do you think the following services should be\nrun in the private sector or the public sector?",
    caption = "Base: All Respondents Unweighted Total: Total=1858"
  )









How does the improved visualization look different than the original? Does it send a different message at a first glance?

Yes, the improved visualization sends a much different message. Now, at first glance, it is more obvious that, regardless of service, most individuals voted that they should be handled in the public sector instead of the private or don’t know. Before, the differences within sector were less obvious due to poor scaling.

title: Data science ethics
text:
Title






Welcome




Misrepresentation




Data privacy

title: Welcome
text:
Data science ethics


Misrepresentation
Data privacy
Algorithmic bias

title: Data privacy
text:
“Your” data

Every time we use apps, websites, and devices, our data is being collected and used or sold to others.
More importantly, decisions are made by law enforcement, financial institutions, and governments based on data that directly affect the lives of people.

title: Data privacy
text:
Privacy of your data

What pieces of data have you left on the internet today? Think through everything you’ve logged into, clicked on, checked in, either actively or automatically, that might be tracking you. Do you know where that data is stored? Who it can be accessed by? Whether it’s shared with others?

title: Data privacy
text:
Sharing your data

What are you OK with sharing?





Name
Age
Email
Phone Number
List of every video you watch
List of every video you comment on
How you type: speed, accuracy





How long you spend on different content
List of all your private messages (date, time, person sent to)
Info about your photos (how it was taken, where it was taken (GPS), when it was taken)

title: Data privacy
section: What does Google think/know about you?
text:
What does Google think/know about you?

Have you ever thought about why you’re seeing an ad on Google? Google it! Try to figure out if you have ad personalization on and how your ads are personalized.

title: Data privacy
text:
Your browsing history

Which of the following are you OK with your browsing history to be used towards?



For serving you targeted ads
To score you as a candidate for a job
To predict your race/ethnicity for voting purposes

title: Data privacy
section: Who else gets to use your data?
text:
Who else gets to use your data?

Suppose you create a profile on a social media site and share your personal information on your profile. Who else gets to use that data?



Companies the social media company has a connection to?
Companies the social media company sells your data to?
Researchers?

title: Data privacy
text:
OK Cupid data breach

In 2016, researchers published data of 70,000 OkCupid users—including usernames, political leanings, drug usage, and intimate sexual details
Researchers didn’t release the real names and pictures of OKCupid users, but their identities could easily be uncovered from the details provided, e.g. usernames

title: Data privacy
text: OK Cupid data breach

title: Data privacy
text:
OK Cupid data breach

Some may object to the ethics of gathering and releasing this data. However, all the data found in the dataset are or were already publicly available, so releasing this dataset merely presents it in a more useful form.
Researchers Emil Kirkegaard and Julius Daugbjerg Bjerrekær

title: Data privacy
text:
Data privacy

In analysis of data that individuals willingly shared publicly on a given platform (e.g. social media), how do you make sure you don’t violate reasonable expectations of privacy?
